body: cc @GeorgesStavracas if you have any thoughts
On software rendering (eg. `LIBGL_ALWAYS_SOFTWARE=true`) [init_format_info](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/plugins/linux-pipewire/pipewire.c#L346) won't contain any format.

issue.title: linux-pipewire: Check format availablity against DRM only for dmabufs

labels.name: Bug Fix
labels.description: Non-breaking change which fixes an issue

milestone.title: OBS Studio 29.0

Items that we would like to consider for inclusion in OBS Studio 29.

NOTE: Items on this list are not promised to be in the listed release, just that we are considering them. This list is subject to change at any time.

repository.description: OBS Studio - Free and open source software for live streaming and screen recording

issue.body:
<!--- Please fill out the following template, which will help other contributors review your Pull Request. -->

<!--- Make sure youâ€™ve read the contribution guidelines here: https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst -->

### Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail. -->
<!--- If this change includes UI elements, please include screenshots. -->

Fixes pipewire-screencast when using a software renderer

### Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open GitHub Issue, or implements feature request -->
<!--- from the Ideas page, please link to the issue here. -->

Whe using a software renderer there will be no formats available for using with dmabufs. We should only consider those formats wrt. to modifiers and as such move this check after adding general support for that format.

Fixes #7985 

### How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment (hardware, OS version, etc.),-->
<!--- and the tests you ran, including how it may affect other areas of code. -->
Run obs with `LIBGL_ALWAYS_SOFTWARE=true`

### Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your PR introduce? Uncomment all that apply -->
- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
<!--- - New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) -->
<!--- - Tweak (non-breaking change to improve existing functionality) -->
<!--- - Performance enhancement (non-breaking change which improves efficiency) -->
<!--- - Code cleanup (non-breaking change which makes code smaller or more readable) -->
<!--- - Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change) -->
<!--- - Documentation (a change to documentation pages) -->

### Checklist:
<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->
- [x] My code has been run through [clang-format](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/.clang-format).
- [x] I have read the [**contributing** document](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst).
- [x] My code is not on the master branch.
- [x] The code has been tested.
- [x] All commit messages are properly formatted and commits squashed where appropriate.
- [x] I have included updates to all appropriate documentation.

body: I'm afraid I'd have to fix this to actually provide more feedback on what's going on

> This might be related to what I just tracked down while working out kinks with new hardware.

I could not replicate this i with i915/nvidia-drm drivers, I just set an assert on build_format's return value, and it seems they do not report as many modifiers as whatever system you are on. e.g. https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/d8f2db7b84d5 or https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/bb72f61358be 

The most popular amdgpu cards also dont report so many modifiers (or any): 580 series https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/bff76074682d,  5xxx series:https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/5e48acec4633 but looking at the 7xxx series it seems they have kept adding more: https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/d5dc1c516b42

if there is a way to compute the required size of our builder sending a patch for sizing would be good.

--- edit
Also file another issue for that, since this will be closed by the pending PR.

> The most popular amdgpu cards also dont report so many modifiers

Hadn't seen `drmdb` before; thanks! Looks like others have it covered, but here's mine, essentially the same, on `6.2-rc2` (with a couple patches for fan control for the same card, which is I assume why it shows as unknown): https://drmdb.emersion.fr/snapshots/c5ebcec71038

Since it doesn't *quite* make sense to me that such a small set of data would be eating up 2KB+, I want to confirm that there's not something else going on before I send something needless in, but thanks, and I'll send something after some due diligence.

> With the number of supported modifiers on formats growing, (11 on all relevant formats for me at the time of writing), we actually out-grow the 2048-byte buffer we were using to construct the SPA version of the format params. This _seems_ a bit excessive, but I don't know how the internals of `spa_pod_builder` work, so once I confirmed this I didn't look too much farther to see if we're leaking something temporarily there.

This is independent from this issue. But yeah, we need to calculate the required size for all EnumFormats.

> It wouldn't be a bad idea to add some defensive coding to prevent the "trying the same params twice" case to prevent an actual logic issue in the future, but in the immediate time frame, simply increasing the buffer size from 2048->4096 resolves it (at least with my hardware). 

We don't try the same params twice. A modifier is always dependent on the used format. If a modifier don't work for a given format we drop it, but the same modifier value might work with another format. Also if we update our EnumFormats, we have to announce everything we support. Otherwise the producer might have issues with our selected subset and can't choose a valid pair.

> We don't try the same params twice

100% agreed with all the logic, but... I think what I failed to say since I'm new to this ecosystem is that **this is** the behavior that is triggered by encountering the aforementioned overflow. Despite the call to `pw_update_stream_params` being initiated (observed w/ debugger), the presence of null values in `params` triggers (likely undefined) downstream behavior, that I observed to be pipewire taking *no action whatsoever* in terms of actual updates in response to the call. This means we print "Renegotiating format", but never actually get that far, and repeatedly fail to use the DMA-BUF in our rendering API (exactly as is in the logs in the OP).

I realize this is *very likely* only tangentially related if there are logic failures that cause circumstances other than this to trigger similar symptoms. I think we're all on the same page there; That said, the desktop hardware support stack(s) are a a painfully broad, and oft lonely experience to independently learn on one's own, so after spending far too long ramping up to track down what ended up being a simple lack of buffer space, I'll take whatever good discussion for learning I can get out of it, and hopefully save some poor google'ing sap some time in the process.

> If a modifier don't work for a given format we drop it, but the same modifier value might work with another format

This was my assumption too based on my limited understanding, but at least for my current version of `firefox` (`100.0.1`), it's webrtc implementation of pipewire dma-buf sharing *does* remove a given modifier from *all* formats during each round of attempted negotiation. Thanks for confirming my suspicion that the OBS implementation was more correct! I spent far too long chasing that red herring while getting my bearings yesterday
